qas.question: When did the French language adopt the word 'police'?
What language did French borrow the word 'police' from?
Which dictionary said police were 'a symbol of foreign oppression'?
When were the Marine Police created in the UK?
What was the first use of 'police' in the UK?

answers.text: the appointment of Commissioners of Police for Scotland in 1714

qas.question: When did the English language adopt the word 'police'?
What language did French not borrow the word 'police' from?
Which dictionary said police were 'a symbol of local oppression'?
When were the Marine Police created in France?
What was the last use of 'police' in the UK?

context: The word "police" was borrowed from French into the <a1_0><b6_0>English<b6_0/><a1_0/> language <a0_0>in the <b5_0>18th century<b5_0/><a0_0/>, but for a long time it applied only to French and continental European police forces. The word, and the concept of police itself, were "disliked as a symbol of foreign oppression" (according to <a2_0><b7_0>Britannica 1911<b7_0/><a2_0/>). Before the 19th century, the first use of the word "police" recorded in government documents in the United Kingdom was <a4_0>the appointment of Commissioners of Police for Scotland in <b9_0>1714<b9_0/><a4_0/> and the creation of the Marine Police in <a3_0><b8_0>1798<b8_0/><a3_0/>.
